@hannahcwiley Of course. I‚Äôm trying to improve the situation:

https://t.co/jTp1meS3xo
@vlaekershner Fair point. See previous tweets.

@philwillon This is not about your quality work in reporting the news. It is about the depletion of civic journalism and the stories that don‚Äôt get told. It is also about the gaps in storytelling that miss important activities that go to the heart of the protection of our Dem institutions.

@akoseff A large # of the media outlets in the nation are gone in the past 20 or so years. Sacramento capitol coverage is a shadow of what it used to be. I‚Äôm not knocking those doing this work today. I‚Äôm trying to get your attention to fundamental issues underpinning our democracy.
@ZavalaA Agree. It is deserving of criticism and analysis. My own observation is the newer members have little experience in journalistic oversight and also don‚Äôt feel it matters. All bad.

@HankPlante Exactly. Of course there are many good reporters burning the midnight oil. But what news hole are they filling and who is reading/listening to it?  And where is the focus on fundamental matters affecting our democracy?
@akoseff Missing the point.

@Frannydink @CalMatters I agree that they do very good work. But will it solve the serious depletion of local and state reporting and oversight? The answer is no. We can still appreciate their important contribution and acknowledge the serious shortcomings in protecting our democracy.

@hannahcwiley Not in the least. There are only two around now who remember the rigor and oversight in the 1970s (Walters and Skelton); in the 80s (Barabak and some general assignments); a few in the 90s (Mehta). I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôve missed some still writing. The erosion and consequence is the story.

I‚Äôll answer. What each writer believes is important is the outcome and impact of power: party power, interest group power and the short term consequences to people. Lost in this fog of political coverage is the health of our democracy. How do theses measures sustain or erode it?

@JewishonCampus_ . . righteousness on a slippery slope to bigotry. I hope there can be constructive conversation about our mutual goals for justice, liberty, and human rights throughout the world. Thinking globally and acting locally do matter. Choose thoughtfully.
@HankPlante Of course you‚Äôre right. So what can we do about it?

Unfortunately, there are less than 1 dozen journalists staying up tonight to report on the signing or vetoing of hundreds of bills on the Ca Governor‚Äôs desk. Pretty sad situation. So what matters? Our democracy? Civic journalism so the numbers grow rather than shrink? Think hard.

10 questions we should answer before our state and counties reopen further. https://t.co/v8yCTnO6Oa

More C19 testing helps track, trace and quarantine but random testing provides real data on spread and knowledge about ‚Äúhow‚Äù- so we can close those gaps. Any reopening that fails to employ valid research tools is tempting more than fate. It‚Äôs ignoring science. @erinallday

More than 3,000 new covid 19 cases in Cal today. What is our ability to track, trace and quarantine them? Where have they been - essential workers, sheltering in place, transit riders, nursing homes? How can we ‚Äúreopen‚Äù without having basic data to try to lower infections?

Yes but...we also have to ask direct questions about goals, data, risks, and economic and health impact models. Reopening prematurely can creat big setbacks and erode public trust. https://t.co/1pvuP7EAF9

I embrace the argument that ‚Äúgovernment closer to the people is better.‚Äù But when we‚Äôre dealing with a virus that crosses county and state borders in a blink of the eye, we need central government authority in order to make the best decisions. Are we all in this together?
10. Does lowering the infection rate remain the top state goal or has it been replaced with a desire to reopen the economy even if infection rates go up? If so, how high a rate will be acceptable?
9. As we re-open restaurants for indoor dining, how will we know if doing so leads to faster spread of the virus?
8. What are the state and county audit and oversight activities in the reopening? Is waiting until infections and hospitalizations spike, two to four weeks later, too late?

7. @GavinNewsom  outlined six indicators the state would consider when modifying the Stay at Home order, including the ability to protect those at high risk for COVID-19. How does his reopening do this?

6. The virus is spread most easily in crowded living conditions, which are more common in lower-income neighborhoods hit hardest by the economic slowdown. How can we offer more help? Alternate housing for those who test positive?
5. Nursing home vulnerabilities have been known for months. Despite saying they are a priority for testing, why are we not testing every resident and staff person on a regular basis?
4. Why are we not doing regular scientifically monitored tests of random samples of the population to show the extent of asymptomatic infections, overall infections and rate of spread?

3. The number of tests being conducted is valuable for tracking, tracing and isolation of individual cases. But aren‚Äôt these test results insufficient for broader use because of the motivation of the person requesting the test?

2. More than 2,000 Californians are still testing positive every day. How many of these people have been under sheltering-in-place orders and how many are essential workers who were exposed outside the home?

10 questions we should answer as our state reopens further: 

1. Based on testing and hospitalization data, it appears there are more COVID 19 infections today than when sheltering in place began on March 20. If so, why are we loosening restrictions?

Thanks to @QuirkSilva2018 and 28 co-authors, we initiate the fight to help our poorest renters in California today with #SB248 to increase their tax credit from $60 up to $434 for single moms and dads. 2.4 millions renters will get quick help. 40 years of waiting is long enough!
